p: The application of ethnopharmacological/chemotaxonomic-based strategies is important to optimize studies of botanical anthelmintic agents in order to increase the success of developing new plant-derived or herbal agents of interest for the pharmaceutical-veterinary industry [ 10]. Although in vivo studies are still needed, the present work preliminarily validates the ethnopharmacological and chemotaxonomic data that indicate the use of C. aurantifolia, A. nobile and L. officinalis as anthelmintics. This is the first study testing the essential oils of these plants against H. contortus, highlighting their ethnopharmacological use and pharmaceutical-veterinary value.
